awd_titl_txt: OP: Quantum Optical Physics with Nanophotonics Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Atoms (the particles that constitutes ordinary matter) and light interact with each other through absorption and emission of photons (individual quanta or particles of light). Such atom-photon interactions constitute one of the most basic processes in physical science, and underlie many everyday phenomena as well as many device applications in areas such as optoelectronics. Most of these processes and devices involve large numbers of atoms and intense beams of light, since the interaction between single atoms and single photons are typically negligibly weak. The interaction can be made substantial if one builds a system in which an atom interacts with light confined in a very small space. Such strong atom-photon interactions lead to many new phenomena that not only deepen our understanding of nature, but may also form the basis of future technologies. These include novel transistors based on individual photons interacting with each other, novel states of matter in which atoms and photons are intertwined with one another, and robust quantum information systems that enable advances such as secure communication over long distances and ultra-precise quantum sensors. The present research program will explore new physics by using precisely engineered hybrid systems that combine nanoscale solid structures for confining light with well-isolated atoms and "atom-like" features (color centers) in solids.

Specifically, the present project aims at (1) understanding interactions between ultra-cold atoms and solid-state atom-like systems with photons confined to sub-wavelength photonic and plasmonic structures, (2) creating and controlling non-classical states of light and, (3) manipulating multi-atom quantum dynamics within hybrid quantum systems of increasing complexity. The project will also explore new theoretical approaches that focus on quantum dynamics of strongly interacting photons and atoms, with emphasis on using coherent and dissipative mechanisms to control quantum many-body states. The proposed effort will not only create new hybrid systems where many ideas of quantum optics can be realized, tested, and refined, but also lay the groundwork for a number of applications, ranging from realizations of robust quantum information systems and quantum optical circuits operating at the single photon level to the development of nanoscale sensors for studying complex systems. The principal investigators will also continue to develop new and efficient ways for disseminating physics knowledge through teaching, collaborations, review articles, lecture notes, organization of workshops and summer schools. To enhance the appreciation and understanding of science by the general public, outreach efforts such as visits to local K-12 schools will be combined with colloquia and public talks.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes. Research within this program was aimed at exploring fundamental physics and potential applications of controlled quantum systems at the interface of quantum optics and nanoscience. It involved the interplay between theory and experiment as well as investigation of potential applications of quantum optical control using nanophotonic systems. The unifying theme of this work is the exploration of controlled quantum systems of increasing complexity, which is among the outstanding challenges in quantum science.

Key results include realization a programmable quantum system capable of high-fidelity manipulation of large arrays of individual trapped atoms. This system has recently emerged as one of the leading platforms for quantum information processing and quantum simulations. Specific highlights include coupling isolated ultracold atoms to photonic crystal cavities, realization of a single photon phase switch and photon-mediated interactions between two trapped atoms, realization of a new approach for atom-by-atom control of arrays consisting of up to 60 atoms and their applications for quantum information processing.

Research on quantum control of atom-like impurities in the solid-state bridged the gap between isolation and strong interactions and showed that such systems may enable unique applications ranging from realization of new states of matter to quantum networking & long-distance quantum communication. In addition, we began to explore a new family of optical emitters in two-dimensional semiconductor materials. Specific highlights of this effort include: discovery and development of a new family of color centers (SiV, GeV, etc.) with superior optical properties; strong coupling of such color centers to nanophotonic waveguides and cavities in diamond and efficient interface with conventional fibers; realization of an integrated single photon switch (using both SiV and GeV color centers); first realization of quantum entanglement of solid-state qubits within a nanophotonic device, photon-mediated interaction between two SiV centers; realization of long-lived quantum memory using SiV centers and  memory-enhanced quantum communication, a key component of quantum repeater for long-distance quantum communication; realization of integrated nanophotonic/plasmonic circuits and optical hyperbolic metasurfaces; and realization of atomically thin mirrors and efficient exciton coupling to plasmonic systems in two-dimensional semiconductors.

Finally, we carried out theoretical work on quantum dynamics of strongly interacting photons, and nanomechanics and development of new protocols and applications to quantum networking and quantum metrology.

 Broader Impact. Our work stimulated development of a new discipline of quantum science and engineering. We contributed to forming this discipline by conducting cutting edge research, as well as through efforts in education and innovation. For instance, both PIs have developed and taught new graduate and undergraduate courses whose materials draw from the research collaboration. Some of these course materials (such as lecture notes on modern AMO physics and a new undergraduate quantum information course that are openly available online) are already being used widely by students and educators around the world. Over the past two decades we trained several dozens of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, many of whom went on to successful research carriers in academia, national labs and industry. We have filed multiple patent disclosures and are serving as scientific advisors to two startup companies created by our former group members in different areas of quantum technology.
